Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 12:12PM Paulette531 wrote: Heather...I finished Taxol in October of 2004 and still have neuropathy in both feet and from my right side of my neck down to my right foot (my neurologist said 5-7 years it will heal, if at all). The neurologist did massive testing and one thing was that I was anemic where vitamin b6 is concerned. B6 is essential for nerves. He also gave me neurontin (sp) but the b6 is really helping. I stopped the neurontin because I am trying not to take a lot of synthetic meds. See if you need your b6 level checked.

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2007 07:24AM Paulette531 wrote: I had recon twice and twice it failed. The last time I landed in the hospital for five days with a staph infection. My breast surgeon said we could try again in six months, six months went by and then two years have gone by and I still have not done it! I probably won't. For the short time that I had the implants, I found them to be very uncomfortable. And after hearing all the ins and outs of the other types of recon I decided it just wasn't for me. If I was younger maybe, but at this stage of the game (59) I think I am just fine as I am. This is a really good thread!

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 05:26PM Paulette531 wrote: No Deb...you did not over react. I had a nurse attempt three times to access my port and on the third attempt I told her if she did not get it this time to kindly leave the room and get someone who could. She did not get it and made a snide comment that she didn't know what the problem was, it doesn't hurt. I blew up and told her to let me stick a needle in her chest three times and let's see how it feels. I reported her to my onc and my onc went ballistic in the chemo ward, I never had another problem. Sometimes medical people lack empathy and really need a course in humanization.
